1111.content:
Ian Chesterton sucked on his cigarette wondering at the ship's ability to recreate this earth drug and it's inability to get them home. The Doctor was pottering around as usual, fiddling with things and hmming and hawing. Barbera was off with Susan talking about something or other. They were supposed to be going home as usual, but it was anyone's guess where they'd end up. Ian was a little glad to away from Susan after her recent idea of 'a fun game'. Barbara seemed as collected as ever but then she hadn't 'won'!

"Chesterton!" Ian's reverie was broken by the familiar sound of an agitated old man. "Look at this! Quite remarkable! Hmm?"

Ian looked at a small screen in a bank of equipment at a lot of squiggles which he couldn't understand.

"I'm sorry Doctor; it's all greek to me!" he admitted.

"My dear boy! Look! This is a reading for Earth! Twentieth century! I do believe you are going home! Eh?"

Ian stared at the screen. He's heard this before, but not with any evidence, even if he couldn't make head nor tail of the evdence. Was this it? Were he and Barbara finally going home?

In a space between times a blue box fell endlessly and at it's destination a short angry Canadian huffed on a cigar and said "I never liked you, and you you just over the line, bub. Say hello to the real me."

*Snikt*

Razor sharp claws burst out of the man's hands as outside an antiquated blue policebox materialised...

114.content:
The Fourth Doctor was making a lonely trip back from Gallifrey, when an unusual spike in tachyonic radiation was detected by the TARDIS scanners. "Well, this looks like an adventure, a wormhole is opening." As he wraps his scarf around his neck preparing to investigate, a sudden jerk takes hold of the TARDIS. "What, some kind of tractor beam?" he scoffed. The TARDIS was drawn to the opening of the wormhole, as if a powerful electromagnetic force was pulling it in. In the control room, many of the systems of the TARDIS begin to fail while the Doctor feverishly tries to recalibrate the dematerialization field. Then, it is as if nothing happened. The Doctor looks around puzzled as to what had just happened. "This is quite unusual, all systems are normal and appears that we've went through the wormhole old girl." A knocking on the TARDIS doors, grabs the Doctor's attention. He quickly glances over the TARDIS computers. "A visit from the depths of space? This keeps getting exciting! Oxygen levels, Earth-like. Gravity, slightly on the Heavy side. And...multiple lifeforms outside, but inside a ship?" The Doctor opens the door and finds that he is surrounded by numerous armed guards. "WELCOME DOC!!!!!" screamed a hideous flab of yellow skin. The monster walks up to the front of the crowd on a robotic spider-like platform. "YOU have no idea how Popular you are here in Mojoworld! and I'm Mojo, writer, producer, and DI-rector!!!!" The Doctor was at a loss, but regain his composure, "This is a party for me, oh you shouldn't have but unfortunately I'm need to investigate a disturbance. Sorry got to go." The the TARDIS doors slam shut right in front of the Doctor as he tried to enter. "OH DOC baby, YOU'RE NOT GOING Anywhere..GUARDS take Mister DOCTOR to his Dressing ROOM at ONCE!!!!!!!!"

Meanwhile, the X-Men where under going training in the Danger Room, when Professor Xavier called them. "Attention all available X-Men, this is Professor X, I need you all to come to my office at once. It is of great importance." sounded the PA. Cyclops, Jean Grey, Storm, Beast and Wolverine where in the Professor's office within a flash. "Yes Professor?" asked Cyclops. "X-Men, we have received a message from Lilandra of the Shi'ar Empire. She needs our assistance in an investigation and relief mission. Apparently an unknown discharge of energy has caused a disaster on one of their colonies." Beast jumped up on to the ceiling, "Professor, will she send transport, I'm afraid the Blackbird is unable to travel faster than light?" The Professor nodded, "Yes, a star cruiser will come and pick us up in about an hour." "No fight, darn. Well I'm ready to go." said Wolverine sarcastically.
Jean walked up to the Professor, "Sir, should we call in the rest of the Team?" Professor answered,"I believe we can manage without Rouge, Gambit, and Jubilee."

Within a few hours, the X-Men and Professor X find themselves on Alstar 3, a mining colony orbiting a gas giant. "Charles, it is good to see you and your X-Men again." Said Empress Lilandra. "What was the cause of this disaster? Solar wind?" asked Beast. "According to the scanners and the royal scientists, it appears that a blast of tachyons hit the moon. Without an atmosphere, the tachyons were not absorbed thus resulting in a backlash of tachyonic radiation." commented Lilandra. "Tachyons, aren't the type of particles that travel faster than light?" asked Cyclops. "Yes, and usually they normally don't do this unless...unless a wormhole has opened from another dimension" Beast said with caution. "Ok then, where's Capt'n Kirk?" Wolverine remarked, "cuz I think we have company." A flash of energy appeared, and out of the portal stumbled out the Doctor.

Then Mojo appeared, "LET THE GAMES BEGIN!!!!!! STARRING THE UNCANNY X-MEN AND IN HIS FIRST APPEARANCE, THE DOCTOR!!!!!!!!! Here on sunny Alstar 3, with a dimensional barrier to keep out those pesky Imperial Guard of the Shi'Ar. They must play to save the mining crew and EMPRESS LILANDRA, HAHAHAHAHAHAHAHA!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Choose your side wisely DOC!"

115332112.content: The Doctor stepped out of the doors, followed by Rose. "Ah, professor Smith" said an old man who Rose assumed must be Charles Xavier, he was sitting in a wheelchair behind a desk and was around 60 or 70 years old. Rose looked around. The TARDIS had appeared in a classroom full of kids. The Doctor noticed too "Oh, sorry about that, you were in the middle of a lesson, should I park the TARDIS round the back?" "I suppose you'd better" said Professor Xavier, then to Rose "What's your name?" "Rose Tyler, I'm travelling with Professor Smith" said Rose, not knowing how much the Professor knew about the Doctor. "Well, Rose, take a seat" said the Professor, turning to his class "For next time, I want a paper on how mutant genes differ from normal genes" The class left. "I haven't seen the Doctor for almost fifty years" said the Professor "He saved my life, I never got to repay him" "When did you meet him" asked Rose "I was 18, I was studying anatomy at university when the Doctor came in as a lecturer, at first, I thought he was just an ordinary person, but then, when I was doing my shift as a guard, I saw him in a corridor with a strange blue device and at one of the top security doors, He asked for my help, showing me his paper, telling me he was supposed to get into the room" "That'll be his psychic paper and sonic screwdriver" said Rose "What happened next?" "I opened the door, I accompanied him inside, there was a strange machine with blood in it, he told me to get out of there, so I ran, then the next day, I was feeling guilty about leaving him and there was a strange noise and this blue box appeared and he stepped out, thanked me for my help and offered me a trip in time and space as a reward, I declined, but he still wanted to give me a rewar, so he gave me a key" he pulled out a key on a chain "He told me that when the key glows, I will be there I always carry this key in case it does" he said "Then, today, it glowed and I knew he was coming, I just didn't know how quickly"

13433122.content:
"Don't move!" said one of the soldiers, as they aimed their guns, each one pointing at a different one of them, while the fifth tracked between the four of them evenly. You raised your hands, along with the other three.
"We're unarmed," you said, while at the same time estimating if you would be able to take them all down. The problem with your powers, was that you couldn't focus them well. If you screamed, you would hit your allies as much as your enemies. Looking up at the stone ceiling, you saw cracks in the roof. If you went too high, you could very well collapse the caves on top of all of you. It wasn't exactly stable. You sized them all up. All 5 were trained soldiers, holding their guns comfortably in their hands, moving in military precision. You couldn't guarantee your friend's safety if you used your powers.
"Look at their hands," said one "They're clean."
The one that seemed to be the leader said "All right, process them. Him first."

Two of the men grabbed the Doctor, shoving his hand into the machine, even as he protested:
"Oi, oi, what's the matter with clean hands?" he shouted.
"Leave him alone!" said Donna
"Let go of him, or I will bring this cave down around us," you said, your voice calm, and collected. A couple of the men actually hesitated, but then the machine activated. The cylinder lit up, and rotated.
"What are you doing to him?" asked Donna, her voice still panicked, but a hint of curiosity in there too.
"Everyone gets processed," said the leader
"It's taken a tissue sample. Ow. And extrapolated it. Some kind of accelerator?" The Doctor inquired, as the cylinder opened, his hand sliding out.

At the same time, the doors began opening, revealing a blonde haired girl, who stepped out, getting given a gun by one of the soldiers.
"Where did she come from?" asked Martha
"From me," The Doctor replied
"What do you mean?" you asked "How did she get here?"
"Well, she's my daughter," said the Doctor
The girl cocked the gun, looked straight at the Doctor and said "Hello Dad,"
13433122.title: Five soldiers come from a corridor to the right...

You get a message from Xavier
134331221.content:
Two blasts of energy came from down the corridor. You saw two fish-like humanoids with cylinders filled with water over their nose and mouth.
"Take cover!" you shouted, running for the wreckage south of the TARDIS, while Martha ran towards the aliens. The 6 soldiers took defensive positions, retreating as they returned fire. One of the soldiers goes down, and the Doctor pulls him out of the way. The girl kicked one of the aliens backwards, wresting the gun from him and regrouping with the other four soldiers.
"We have to blow the tunnel," said the lead soldier, indicating a detonator on the wall.
The girl ran to it, pressing a button and then running down the corridor. You put your head down, as the explosion rocked the tunnel, sending an avalanche of rock down between them and Martha.

The Doctor stood, looking at the rock wall. "You've sealed off the tunnel," then, turning to the girl "Why did you do that!"
"They were trying to kill us," said the girl
"But they've got my friend," he said
"She's collateral, he lost both his men. I'd say you've come out ahead," said the girl
"Her name's Martha," said Donna "And she's not collateral damage, not to anyone. Have you got that, GI Jane?"
"You're going nowhere," said the sergeant "You don't make sense, you three. No guns, no marks, no fight left in you. I'm taking you to General Cobb. Now move!"

As they walked, you talked with the woman
"Do you have a name?" you asked
"Haven't had one assigned yet," she replied
"Well, what do you know, then?" asked Donna. You looked back at her. You admired her to-the-point attitude sometimes, but at others, her bluntness could come off as rudeness.
The girl didn't seem to notice "How to fight."
"Nothing else?" asked Donna
"The machine must embed military history and tactics, but no name. She's a generated anomaly," said the Doctor.
"That's so sad," you said, looking at the nameless woman. Mutants had it bad, but to be brought into existence without even a name to call yourself? You couldn't decide if that was better or worse than the situation for mutants.
"Generated anomaly," Donna said thoughtfully ""Generated" Well how about that? Jenny?"
"Jenny? I like that, Jenny," said the newly-christened Jenny.

Eventually, the tunnels opened out into a large open space reminding you of a theatre at home, but with similar chambers to the one Jenny had come out of lining the walls.
"So where are we? What planet is this?" asked the Doctor
"Messaline," said the leader "What's left of it, anyway. Wait here."
The leader leaves, and returns with an older man.
"General Cobb, I presume," said the Doctor
"Found in the western tunnels, I'm told," said Cobb "With no marks. There was an outbreak of pacifism in the eastern zone before we lost contact."
"That's where we came from," you said "My name is (your name), this is the Doctor, Donna and Jenny."
Jenny smiled at you, as you included her in your introductions.
"Don't think you can infect us with your peace-making," said Cobb "We are at war."
"Yes, I noticed," said the Doctor "With the Hath. But tell us, because we've been out of circulation, eastern zone and all that, so who exactly are the Hath?"
"At the dawn of this planet, these ancient halls were carved from the earth. Our ancestors dreamed of a new beginning," Cobb had a vacant look in his eyes, as if he was imagining what he was speaking of "A colony of human and Hath, living and working together."
You couldn't help but draw parallels to your own experiences in Xavier's School for the Gifted, a school with a similar philosophy to this man's ancestors.
"What happened?" asked the Doctor
Cobb's eyes darkened "The dream died. Broken, along with Hath promises. They wanted it all for themselves. But those early pioneers, they fought back. They used the machines to produce soldiers instead of colonists, and began battle for our survival."
"There's nothing but earth outside, why's that? Why build everything underground? The surface is too dangerous," Cobb replied, not elaborating further.
"Then why build windows in the first place?" asked the Doctor "And what's this mean?" he indicated symbols on the wall.
"The rites and symbols of our ancestors," said Cobb "Their meanings lost in time."

Cobb leads the group over to a machine powering it up to show a holographic map of tunnels.
"Does this show the entire city, including the Hath zones?" asked the Doctor
"Yes. Why?" asked Cobb
"Well, it'll help us find Martha," said the Doctor
"We've more important things to do," said the leader of the soldiers that had brought them there "The progenation machines are powered down for the night shift, but soon as they're active, we could breed a whole platoon from you two."
"Hold on, I'm only 17," you say "I'm way too young to have kids."
"I'm not having sons and daughters by some great big flipping machine," said Donna "Sorry, no offence, but you're not. Well, I mean, you're not real."
That was Donna. Honest, but sometimes too honest.
"You're no better than him," said Jenny, sounding offended "I have a body, I have a mind, I have independent thought. How am I not real? What makes you better than me?"

"Well said, soldier," said Cobb "We need more like you, if ever we're to find the Source."
"Ooo, the Source," said the Doctor "What's that, then? What's a Source? I like a Source. What is it?"
"The Breath of Life."
"And that would be?"
"In the beginning, the great one breathed life into the universe," it was the squadron leader that answered "And then she looked at what she'd done, and she sighed."
"She. I like that," said Jenny
"Right. So it's a creation myth," said the Doctor
"It's not myth," said Cobb "It's real. That sigh. From the beginning of time it was caught and kept as the Source. It was lost when the war started. But it's here, somewhere. Whoever holds the Source controls the destiny of the planet."

1343312211.content:
"Hang on a minute," said the Doctor, pointing his sonic screwdriver at the map. As he did, more tunnels appeared on the map.

"It's more like a tool than a weapon," you chimed in

13433122112.content:
"Doctor?" said Martha's voice from the other side of the phone.
"Martha, you're alive!" said the Doctor, and there was a ripple of relief in the room. You hadn't known Martha very long, but knew that she had given up travelling with the doctor to live her own life outside of the TARDIS. It was the balance that needed to be struck between travelling with the Doctor, and having a life. Martha had given it up because it was too much for her, while Donna seemed to be travelling towards wanting to travel with the Doctor forever. For you, you didn't see either as the best option. You knew it would hurt the Doctor to see his companions grow older, only to die, with him not ageing a day. At the same time, going back to a normal life after everything you had seen while travelling with the Doctor wasn't a good idea either. Knowing it was all out there, and knowing that you couldn't ever travel there again. Like an old Japanese tale you'd heard once, of a spirit called Kue Kuatsu, who came to the real world to pick flowers for the moon, not knowing that once you leave the spirit world, you can never go back. The Doctor was like the moon, in a sense, always moving onwards, never looking back for long, never resting. Always on to the next thing. Martha wasn't the first person to have left the TARDIS crew, and she wouldn't be the last.
"Where are you?" asked the Doctor
"I'm in the Hath camp. I'm okay, but something's going on," said Martha, who was surprisingly calm considering the situation. Another indicator of a seasoned TARDIS traveller "The Hath are all marching off to some place that's appeared on this map thing."
"Oh, that was me," said the Doctor "With both armies heading there, it's going to be a bloodbath."
"What do you want me to do?" asked Martha
"Just stay where you are," said the Doctor, sternly "If you're safe there, don't move, you hear?"
"But I can help," said Martha. There was silence for a second, then a dial tone.
"Honestly, Doctor," you said "Did you really expect her to just sit tight? When you take us onto the TARDIS, we might be ordinary people, but over the course of our adventures with you, we can't help it. We become heroes. And heroes don't sit tight while there's something they could do to save a few more lives."
You were cut off, as they heard General Cobb speaking "The doors that were closed will be open to us now. The door to the Temple, to the Source, and to victory!"
Cheers followed this.
"Come the dawn cycle, we march," Cobb finished.
"To war," shouted several soldiers.

"They're getting ready to move out," said the Doctor "We have to get past that guard."
"I can help," said Jenny, before you could open your mouth.
"No, no, no, no, you're not going anywhere," said the Doctor
"What?" asked Jenny, confusion and hurt in her voice.
"You belong here, with them," said the Doctor.
"I don't agree, Doctor," you said "You look at her, and you only see the soldier, the weapon, one of Cobb's fanatics. I look at the same person, and I see the child that's seen too much. She doesn't know who she should follow, yet she was bred to follow orders. She's making an effort here, to be on your side, Doctor, and you need to listen, instead of closing your mind off to it."
"Have you got that stethoscope?" asked Donna, of the Doctor "Give it here."
Donna took the stethoscope, and placed it in two places on Jenny's chest.
"Now, you listen, and tell me where she belongs," said Donna. The Doctor did. Jenny looked very confused.
"Two hearts," said the Doctor, and your eyes widened.
"Does that mean she's... what do you call a female Time Lord?" asked Donna
"What's a Time Lord?" asked Jenny
"It's who I am, it's where I'm from," said the Doctor
"And I'm from you," stated Jenny
"You're an echo, that's all. A Time Lord is so much more," said the Doctor. There was fire in his eyes, but it was like the last embers before the fire went out "A sum of knowledge, a code, a shared history, a shared suffering. Only it's gone now, all of it. Gone forever."
"What happened?" you found yourself asking
"There was a war," said the Doctor, still addressing his words to Jenny, but shifting to include you, too.
"Like this one?" asked Jenny
"Bigger. Much bigger."
"And you fought, and killed?"
"Yes."
"Then how are we different?" asked Jenny
"Look," you said "I get you two are kind of having a moment here, but if we want to stop the fighting, I reckon we should get to it. I suggest you cover your ears."

You turned to the cell doors, and screamed.

134331221121.content:
The force of your scream tore the door away from the wall, and through the door on the other side. The guard that had been outside the room seemed to be unconscious on the ground.
There was silence in the room for a moment, as the Doctor, Jenny and Donna removed their hands from their ears.
"Blimey," said the Doctor "That was unexpected."
"Can you two do that?" asked Jenny, looking at the Doctor and Donna, the later of which shook her head. For once, Donna Noble was speechless.
"Look, I'll explain later," you said "We've got more pressing concerns, like who heard that scream?"

The Doctor led the way, until they came to the bottom of a staircase with another number on a wall near it. Down another corridor, two soldiers stood guard.
"I've got this one," Donna said, quietly "I have picked up a few womanly wiles over the years."
You had to put your fist in your mouth to stop from laughing out loud, as the Doctor put his hand on Donna's shoulder. He produced a clockwork mouse from his jacket, using that to distract the guards, so they could get past. However, while they were distracted, Jenny knocked them out.
"I was trying to distract them, not clobber them!" said an exasperated Doctor
"Well, it worked, didn't it?" said Jenny
You searched the guards body, and brought up a holographic representation of the map the Doctor had made appear.
"We'd better hurry," you say "If they've uploaded the map, they must already be on their way."

The four of them moved down corridors, The Doctor navigating. You took the opportunity to talk to Jenny out of earshot of the Doctor and Donna.

Now, I've just found out that my dad and me are the last members of an alien race, and that he travels the universe. What you really want to know, is, if I'm going to turn on you later, and I can say I certainly will not. Whatever I was when I came out of that machine, I'm different now."

The door opens, just as they heard Cobb's voice behind them.

1351.content:
Q was working on some new gadgets for MI6 Special Operations, when the man of which this reality revolved came to him.
"Ah, Mr Bond," said Q "Off to Venice I hear."
"That's right, Q," said Bond "It's our old enemy Spectre again."
"I've just been working on some new gadgets for some of our younger agents," said Q "The other day, I added a couple of new rocket launchers to your new car."
Q led him over to a red Ferari, with no roof.
"Don't you think this is a bit conspicuous?" asked Bond, looking at the car doubtfully.
Q pressed a button on the dashboard. The mirrors folded in, the back wheels got larger and a roof came over the top. Before long, there was a jeep standing there.
"The latest in camouflage technology, there are machine guns built into the doors and the exhaust has spikes in it," Q continued "This car is the only gadget I'm allowed to give you, 007, you've lost so much MI6 equipment, we can't afford to give you more, i'd ask you to bring this back in one piece, but I know you won't listen."
Bond smiled. "Good bye Q,"
James Bond walked out of the gadget room of MI6 headquarters. As soon as the doors closed behind him, Q walked to a book case at the back of the room and pulled out a book. The moment he did, the book case dissolved. As he walked through, it reformed behind him. A bank of computers sat in the middle of the bright room he stood in. These computers were well in advance of anything found in the Multiverse. But these computers were necessary to fly his ship between the realities. They would also pick up on any anomalies that disrupted the other realities, such as other Qs causing mischief.
Q frowned. One of the computers, showing the Marvelverse, had a small blip in it. It could have been nothing, but it was a disturbance in the time line, and he was sure it was by a Q. What were they thinking, the Q thought, their tinkering with time would draw the Time Lords into it. It was probably nothing to worry about, Q decided, most of the Time Lords were dead, save one. The Doctor. This every Q knew. Suddenly, Q saw the reason one of his kin had tampered with time. They wanted to draw the Last of the Time Lords in to destroy them. As much as the Q did not get involved with the Time Lords, this particular Q could not let one of his race commit genocide by killing the Doctor. The former MI6 Q set in the calculations for the jump from the Bondverse to the Marvelverse, then his Quantum Analysis Generally Gallivanting Apparition (Qagga) started to glow, and he sat down in a seat next to the computer bank, and waited patiently for the Qagga to land.

1352.content: This particular Q wasn't just mischievous, he was evil. It was, in fact, him who created mutants in the first place. He wanted to create as much mischief as possible in the universe, and he knew that the best way to do that was through simple natural selection. All beings feared what they do not understand, and the Human Race were no different. The Q Lord made plans. He buried a device on the home planet of the Celestials, a race of powerful beings. When they found the device, they would run tests on it to see what it was, but these tests would take place on test subjects all over the universe. The by product of all this was that mutants were created, and they were immediately shunned by the populations of the planets they were created on. The Mischievous Q laughed with glee as he watched the course of time change. Normally, this type of time altering would have sparked a confrontation with the Time Lords, but, as the Q knew, the Time Lords were extinct. They were wiped out in the last Great Time War. Or so the Q thought...
